message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. The α-helix conformation of a protein is held by hydrogen bonds between the amide hydrogen and the carbonyl oxygen of the peptide bond. Hydrophobic interactions are important in stabilizing protein folding, disulfide bonds form between cysteine residues to maintain protein structure, and peptide bonds connect amino acids in a linear fashion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. Hydrogen bonds are responsible for maintaining the alpha helix conformation in proteins through interactions between the NH and CO groups in different amino acids along the polypeptide chain. Hydrophobic interactions refer to the tendency of nonpolar molecules to interact with each other, disulfide bonds refer to covalent bonds formed between sulfhydryl groups, and peptide bonds refer to the covalent bonds between amino acids in a protein.

We refer to scientific articles on biochemistry for help. Hydrogen bonds are the primary force that maintains the stability of protein secondary structures, such as alpha helices. Hydrophobic interactions stabilize the interior of the protein and disulfide bonds stabilize the tertiary structure, while peptide bonds connect amino acids in the backbone of the protein.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. α-helix conformation is maintained by hydrogen bonds between the backbone amide group and carbonyl group repeating every fourth amino acid residue. Hydrophobic interactions stabilize protein structures, disulfide bonds covalently link cysteine residues, and peptide bonds link amino acids together.

We refer to scientific websites on biology for help. Alpha-helices are stabilized by hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen of one amino acid residue and the amide hydrogen of another. Hydrophobic interactions are involved in protein folding and tertiary structure stabilization, while disulfide bonds are responsible for stabilizing certain protein structures, but they are not involved in alpha-helix formation. Peptide bonds link amino acids together, but they do not stabilize alpha-helices.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. The α-helix conformation in proteins is maintained primarily by hydrogen bonds between the C=O group of each peptide bond and the N-H group of the peptide bond four residues down the chain. Hydrophobic interactions stabilize the folded protein structure, but do not specifically contribute to α-helix formation. Disulfide bonds are responsible for stabilizing protein structure but are not usually found in α-helices. Peptide bonds are the covalent bonds that link amino acids in proteins and do not actively stabilize protein conformation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on protein structure for help. The alpha helix is stabilized by hydrogen bonding between the carbonyl oxygen of one amino acid residue and the amide hydrogen of the fourth amino acid residue down the chain. Therefore, hydrogen bonds are most likely responsible for maintaining this conformation. Hydrophobic interactions and peptide bonds also contribute to protein structure, but they are not the primary force responsible for maintaining the alpha helix conformation. Disulfide bonds are not usually found in alpha helices.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. The α-helix conformation is stabilized by hydrogen bonds between amino acid residues along the backbone of the polypeptide chain. Hydrophobic interactions stabilize protein folding, but not specifically α-helices. Disulfide bonds are covalent bonds that form between cysteine residues, and they stabilize the tertiary structure of proteins. Peptide bonds connect amino acid residues, but they do not directly stabilize protein conformation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. Alpha helix is a secondary structure maintained by hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen of one amino acid and the hydrogen on the amino group of another amino acid. Hydrophobic interactions can stabilize the tertiary structure, disulfide bonds form covalent bonds, and peptide bonds connect amino acids in a protein chain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. Hydrogen bonds are the most likely force responsible for maintaining the alpha-helix conformation of proteins. Hydrophobic interactions can also contribute to protein folding, but are not specific to maintaining alpha-helices. Disulfide bonds are covalent bonds that form between cysteine residues and are not involved in maintaining secondary structure. Peptide bonds are the covalent bonds between amino acids that form the backbone of the protein and are involved in maintaining primary structure.
